data.name: Chess Compression
data.description:
A chessboard configuration can be described using an 8x8 grid (array of 8 strings, each being 8 characters long):

```
[0] RNBQKBNR
[1] PPPPPPPP
[2] ........
[3] ........
[4] ........
[5] ........
[6] pppppppp
[7] rnbqkbnr
```

The case of the letter determines the player

```
Pieces:
P = Pawn
R = Rook
N = Knight
B = Bishop
Q = Queen
K = King
. = Empty square
```

For simplicity, this can be reduced to a 64-character string:

`RNBQKBNRPPPPPPPP........................................pppppppprnbqkbnr`

```
```

__Write 2 functions__:

_compress_

Compress a chessboard configuration string into an array of bits (an array of numbers, each being 0 or 1)

_deCompress_

decompress a bit array (that the compress function provides) and return the original 64-character chessboard configuration string

A constant called _targetCompressionBitArraySize_ is also required
- This is used when performing tests
- It is also used to show how effective your method is as your submission will clearly show your level of compression
- You determine the best compression method. It is possible to compress to 156 bits (maybe less)
- The result of the compress function must *always* return the same size array of bits regardless of the input string

In the chess configuration string:
- all 32 chess pieces will appear
- all 32 empty squares will appear

The board configuration may not be one that is physically possible during a game (for the tests the board contents are simply shuffled - pieces are not legally moved)
